translated: Elder’s Birth Stories🔽The Chapter with Sihāsani
Sopāka Elder’s Birth Story
While I was clearing away the rubble
in the forest on the best of mountains,
the Fortunate One named Siddhattha
came into my presence.

analyzed: buddham upagatam disvā  loka jeṭṭhassa tādinaḥ
translated: Having seen the Buddha come🔽to the Elder of the world, the Tamed One,
having prepared a seat,🔽I gave him a flower seat.
Having sat down on the flower seat,
Siddhattha, the Leader of the world,
having understood my destination,
spoke about impermanence.
‘Impermanent, alas, are all compounded things,
they are subject to arising and ending,
having arisen, they cease again,
their stilling is blissful.’
Having said this, the Omniscient One,
the Elder of the world, the Best of Men,
the Hero rose up into the sky,

analyzed: ambare  sakam diṭṭhim jahitvāna  bhāvaya an icca saññaha
translated: like a King of Swans in the sky.🔽Having given up my own view,🔽I developed the perception of impermanence,
having developed it for one day,
I died there.
Having experienced two successes,
urged on by the root of merit,
in my last existence I was reborn
in a womb of a pig.
Having gone forth from the home life,
I went forth into homelessness,
Seven years old at the time of my birth,
I attained perfection.
With energy aroused and intent focused,
Well-composed in the precepts,
Having pleased the Great Sage,
I received the higher ordination.
For ninety-four eons
the deed I did then,
I do not recall any bad destination,
this is the fruit of offering flowers.
For ninety-four eons
the perception I developed then,
while developing that perception,
my taints were destroyed.
The four analytical insights,
and the eight liberations,
the six supernormal knowledges were realized,
the Buddha’s instruction was fulfilled.”🔽Thus has it been told by the Elder Sopāka.

original: Itthaṁ sudaṁ āyasmā sopāko thero imā gāthāyo abhāsitthāti.🔽Sopākattherassāpadānaṁ navamaṁ.
analyzed: ittham sudam āyasmā sopākaḥ theraḥ imāḥ gāthāyaḥ abhāsittha ati 🔽sopākattherassa apadānam navama
translated: The Story of the Elder Sopāka is the ninth.
